Reference Data Type Mark Type Range for Exponent Channel for Exponent Channel for Mantissa Tasks Evaluation
references: Over the last decade, researchers have introduced visualizations that separate OMVs into their exponent and mantissa components. The effectiveness of these visualizations was evaluated based on tasks such as value retrieval, sorting, ratio estimation, difference estimation, and trend identification. Hlawatsch et al. [23] introduced the Scale-Stack Bar Chart ( [23] introduced the Scale-Stack Bar Chart (SSB) that visualizes large value ranges by stacking values at multiple scales, beginning from zero and mapping numbers linearly. Following a segmented linear model approach, this visualization demonstrates its effectiveness over traditional linear and logarithmic bar charts for quantitative comparisons. Borgo et al. [4] proposed visualizing exponents and mantissa, using two separate marks, as overlapping bars on a linear scale within a classic bar chart, termed Order of Magnitude Markers ( [4] proposed visualizing exponents and mantissa, using two separate marks, as overlapping bars on a linear scale within a classic bar chart, termed Order of Magnitude Markers (OMM). Their approach showcased high accuracy for value retrieval and comparison tasks. Höhn et al. [25] introduced the Width-Scale Bar Charts ( [25] introduced the Width-Scale Bar Charts (WSB), which uses position Y for the mantissa and a redundant combination of color intensity and width for the exponent. They compared WSB with SSB in a controlled experiment, showing that WSB is more effective for value retrieval and SSB for sort, ratio, and trend tasks. Additionally, Braun et al. [7] illustrated the use of color, specifically their Order of Magnitude Color ( [7] illustrated the use of color, specifically their Order of Magnitude Color (OMC) scheme, to aid in perceiving changes in orders of magnitude by mapping exponents to hue and mantissa to a sequential color scale. Lastly, Braun et al. [6], focused on visualizing large-scale time-series data, introducing the Order of Magnitude Horizon Graph ( [6], focused on visualizing large-scale time-series data, introducing the Order of Magnitude Horizon Graph (OMH) and the Order of Magnitude Line chart (OML). OMH modifies the standard horizon graph [22] by using position Y for mantissa and color intensity for the exponents, while [22] by using position Y for mantissa and color intensity for the exponents, while OML combines an approach similar to the segmented linear model that SSB uses for position and the color scheme from OMC. Unlike SSB, where values are shown per magnitude in stacked rows, OML combines both exponent and mantissa in the position Y, introducing a new visualization scale termed “linear scaling within orders of magnitude” [6]. We clarify their scale and call it [6]. We clarify their scale and call it E+M in section 2.3. We summarise the existing literature in Table 1.

The studies highlighted above have conclusively demonstrated the advantages of visualizations that separate OMVs into their mantissa and exponent components. This separation enhances analytical tasks’ accuracy, confidence, and efficiency by offering a more effective representation of large numerical ranges. However, these studies have explored only a subset of the potential combinations of marks and visual channels for encoding the mantissa and exponent (Table 1). Recognizing this gap, our objective is to conduct a systematic exploration of these combinations along with different attribute types: nominal, ordinal, time, and quantitative. By doing so, we aim to identify and discuss which visualizations are most effective for OMVs, proposing guidelines for their representation and enhancing the comprehension of vast numerical data.

references: The 25 visualizations we classified as “Effortless and Effective” are described using eight combinations of visual channels across different marks and attribute types, as shown in Table 2. Through our analysis of these 25 visualizations and their comparison with those requiring more effort, we identified common patterns that are both necessary and sufficient for the effective visualization of OMVs. We present these patterns as design guidelines and recommendations, which are detailed in the following section. The 168 images used in our evaluation are available at https://www.omvs-designspace.com/ and in the supplemental material.
